Stiehm]] | HCYear = 1st | OffCoach = | OCYear = | DefCoach = | DCYear = | OScheme = | DScheme = | StadiumArena = [[Nebraska Field]] | Champion = Nebraska State Champions
Missouri Valley Co-Champions | BowlTourney = | BowlTourneyResult = | ConfChamp = | ConfChampResult = }} {{1911 Missouri Valley football standings}} The '''1911 Nebraska Cornhuskers football team''' was the representative of the [[University of Nebraska-Lincoln|University of Nebraska]] in the [[1911 college football season]]. The team was coached by [[Ewald O. Stiehm]] and played their home games at [[Nebraska Field]] in [[Lincoln, Nebraska]]. ==Before the season== New head coach Stiehm arrived in Lincoln and took over a program with only 17 players on the roster to start the year, however nine of those returners were veteran starters of previous seasons. ==Schedule== {{Cite web|url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=3&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&KEY=&Q_SEASON=1911 |title =Football - 1911 Schedule/Results |accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln Athletics Department}} {| class="wikitable" |- ! Date ! Opponent ! Site ! Result ! Attendance |-align=left style="background: #DDFFDD;" | October 7* | [[University of Nebraska at Kearney|Kearney State]] | Nebraska Field â¢ [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] | '''W''' 117-0 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #DDFFDD;" | October 14* | {{cfb link|year=1911|school=Kansas State Agricultural College|team=Kansas State Aggies|title=Kansas State}} | Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska | '''W''' 59-0 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #FFDDDD;" | October 21* | at [[1911 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]] | Northrop Field â¢ [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] | '''L''' 3-21 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #DDFFDD;" | October 28 | {{cfb link|year=1911|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} | Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska | '''W''' 34-0 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #FFFFE6;" | November 4 | at {{cfb link|year=1911|school=Iowa State College of Agriculture and Mechanical Arts|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | State Field â¢ [[Ames, Iowa]] | '''T''' 6-6 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #DDFFDD;" | November 11* | [[Doane College|Doane]] | Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska | '''W''' 27-0 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #DDFFDD;" | November 18 | at {{cfb link|year=1911|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | Central Park â¢ [[Lawrence, Kansas]] | '''W''' 29-0 | - |- |-align=left style="background: #FFFFE6;" | November 25*â  | [[1911 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]] | Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska | '''T''' 6-6 | - |- |colspan="5"| *Non-Conference Game. â Homecoming. |} ==Roster== * '''Anderson, Arthur''' ''G'' * '''Chauner, Walter''' ''E'' * '''Elliott, E.B.''' ''C'' * '''Frank, Ernest''' ''HB'' * '''Frank, Owen''' ''HB'' * '''Gibson, J.P.''' ''FB'' * '''Harman, Dewey''' ''RT'' * '''Hornberger, Evans''' ''G'' * '''Lofgren, Gus''' ''E'' * '''Pearson, Monte''' ''T'' * '''Potter, Herbert''' ''QB'' * '''Purdy, Leonard''' ''HB'' * '''Russell, Richard''' ''HB'' * '''Shonka, Sylvester''' ''LT'' * '''Swanson, Caesar''' ''LG'' * '''Warner, Leon''' ''QB''{{Cite web|url=http://www.huskers.com/SportSelect.dbml?SPSID=4&SPID=22&DB_OEM_ID=100&Q_SEASON=1911|title=Nebraska Football 1911 Roster|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=University of Nebraska-Lincoln Athletics Department}} ==Coaching staff== {| class="wikitable" |- |align="left"|'''Name'''||align="left"|'''Title'''||align="center"|'''First year
in this position''' ||align="center"|'''Years at Nebraska''' ||align="left"|'''Alma Mater''' |- |'''[[Ewald O. Stiehm]]'''|||Head Coach||align="center"|1911||align="center"|1911â1915|| |- |'''Jack Best'''|||Trainer||align="center"|1890||align="center"|1890â1922|| |} ==Game notes== ===Kearney State=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Kearney State at Nebraska''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | [[University of Nebraska at Kearney|Kearney State]] | || || || | 0 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | '''â¢ Nebraska''' | || || || | 117 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-10-07 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ [[Lincoln, Nebraska]] |} New [[Ewald O. Stiehm|Coach Stiehm]] came out of the box swinging, scoring nearly as many points as were posted in [[Nebraska Cornhuskers football|Nebraska]]'s previous game to end the prior season. Unlike the closing against Haskell in 1910, however, coach Stiehm played backups and substitutes to help establish the starters for the season and yet still piled up an astonishing 117 points, just 2 points shy of the 119-0 record set the year before and resulting the Cornhuskers outscoring their opponents 236-0 in the previous two games. This was the only time Kearney State would face off with the Cornhuskers.{{Cite web|url=http://www.huskermax.com/1910s.html|title=the 1910s|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=HuskerMax}}{{Cite web|url=http://yearbooks.unl.edu/yearbook.php?year=1912&page=37|title=1912 Cornhusker - University of Nebraska Yearbook|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln Libraries}} {{-}} ===Kansas State=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Kansas State at Nebraska''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | {{cfb link|year=1911|school=Kansas State Agricultural College|team=Kansas State Aggies|title=Kansas State}} | || || || | 0 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | '''â¢ Nebraska''' | || || || | 59 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-10-14 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska |} The Cornhuskers met the Kansas State squad for the first time in what would in later years become something of a grudge match between conference foes if not a full blown rivalry, but at this time Kansas State was not in the conference with Nebraska. Coach Stiehm treated Kansas State as he did Kearney State, as a tuneup game to test position players out. Much like the previous week, the Cornhuskers dominated their opponent with another lopsided shutout victory. {{-}} ===Minnesota=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Nebraska at Minnesota''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | Nebraska | || || || | 3 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | '''â¢ [[1911 Minnesota Golden Gophers football team|Minnesota]]''' | || || || | 21 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-10-21 * '''Location:''' Northrop Field â¢ [[Minneapolis|Minneapolis, Minnesota]] |} Minnesota again snatched a victory from Nebraska, extending the futility of the Cornhuskers yet again. Nebraska failed to capitalize on their successes, having outgained Minnesota in rushing, passing and kicking, and fell farther behind the Golden Gophers in the series to 1-9-1. {{-}} ===Missouri=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Missouri at Nebraska''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | {{cfb link|year=1911|school=University of Missouri|team=Missouri Tigers|title=Missouri}} | || || || | 0 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | '''â¢ Nebraska''' | || || || | 34 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-10-28 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska |} {{see also|MissouriâNebraska Rivalry}}Putting aside the annual disappointments in Minnesota, the Missouri contest was Nebraska's 8th straight shutout victory. This series was renewed after a nine-year interruption, and opened the Cornhuskers' Missouri Valley conference slate to start them out 1-0, and 9-3 against the Tigers all-time.{{Cite web|url=http://yearbooks.unl.edu/yearbook.php?year=1912&page=38|title=1912 Cornhusker - [[University of Nebraska]] Yearbook|accessdate=2009-11-16|publisher=University of NebraskaâLincoln Libraries}} {{-}} ===Iowa State=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Nebraska at Iowa State''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | Nebraska | || || || | 6 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | {{cfb link|year=1911|school=Iowa State College of Agriculture and Mechanical Arts|team=Iowa State Cyclones|title=Iowa State}} | || || || | 6 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-11-04 * '''Location:''' State Field â¢ [[Ames, Iowa]] |} Nebraska was understandably feeling confident, having outscored its opponents 473-57 since the beginning of the previous season, with only the losses to Minnesota in each year marring the record. Iowa State had not landed Nebraska back on their home turf in Ames since 1899, and pounced on an unprepared Cornhuskers squad to surprise them by scoring first and holding Nebraska to a 6-6 tie by the end of the day. Iowa still lagged behind Nebraska in the series, though, at 3-8-1. {{-}} ===Doane=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Doane at Nebraska''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | [[Doane College|Doane]] | || || || | 0 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | '''â¢ Nebraska''' | || || || | 27 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-11-11 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska |} Doane came into Lincoln for what was becoming an annual road trip loss for their program, and this one was more of the same. Coach Stiehm used the Doane game as another tuneup match, utilizing substitutes and resting starters on the way to the shutout victory and padding the series lead to 15-2. With wins against both in-state rivals for the year, Nebraska recorded their eighth state championship. {{-}} ===Kansas=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Nebraska at Kansas''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | '''â¢ Nebraska''' | || || || | 29 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | {{cfb link|year=1911|school=University of Kansas|team=Kansas Jayhawks|title=Kansas}} | || || || | 0 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-11-18 * '''Location:''' Central Park â¢ [[Lawrence, Kansas]] |} Kansas was dealt a 0-29 defeat on their home field, considered among the most decisive defeats for the Jayhawks of that time. Nebraska finished their league slate undefeated and improved their record over Kansas to 10-8. {{-}} ===Michigan=== {| class="infobox" style="width:35em; font-size:90%;" |+'''Michigan at Nebraska''' |- | {| class="wikitable" align="right" style="text-align:center; float:right; margin-top:0; margin-right:0;" ! ! width="25" | 1 ! width="25" | 2 ! width="25" | 3 ! width="25" | 4 ! width="25" | Total |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | [[1911 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]] | || || || | 6 |- style="text-align:center;" | align="left" | Nebraska | || || || | 6 |} * '''Date:''' 1911-11-25 * '''Location:''' Nebraska Field â¢ Lincoln, Nebraska |} The match with Michigan was anticipated for much of the season and seen by some as a rematch to settle accounts following Nebraska's loss to the [[Michigan Wolverines Football Club]] in Ann Arbor in 1905. This second meeting of the teams was also the first Homecoming football game for Nebraska. While the Cornhuskers would have preferred a clear victory on the scoreboard, the game was considered a victory of recognition that Nebraska was a football program that would experience sustained success and challenge the college football powers for years to come. {{-}} ==After the season== Coach Stiehm's first year at Nebraska seemed like a continuation of the relative success of the program's past several seasons. The Cornhuskers' program total improved to 123-46-10 (.715), while the conference overall record improved to 7-2-2 (.727). Nebraska and Iowa were named Co-Champions of the Missouri Valley conference. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.huskers.com University of Nebraska Athletics Official Web Site] *[http://www.huskermax.com HuskerMax] {{NebraskaCornhuskersFootballNavbox}} {{DEFAULTSORT:1911 Nebraska Cornhuskers Football Team}} [[Category:1911 NCAA football season|Nebraska]] [[Category:Nebraska Cornhuskers football seasons]]
